body:
- Renamed `gbq_table_exists` to `table_exists`
- Renamed `create_gbq_table` to `create_table`
- Made `project_id` a required parameter in `create_table`
- Reformatted descriptor text in `to_gbq` function into bullet points
- Removed redundant checks in test_gbq.py. eg.  `if PROJECT_ID and not missing_bq()`
- Modify `gbq_read` to support the `destination_table` argument, which allows users to redirect the query results directly to a BigQuery table instead of a pandas DataFrame
- Add `if_exists argument to`gbq_read`and`to_gbq`` to support appending, or replacing a table in GoogleBig Query based on the argument provided.
  - If destination table has a different schema and `if_exists` is set to `append`, raise `InvalidSchemaError`
  - If destination table has a different schema and `if_exists` is set to `replace`, delete and re-create destination table, wait 120 seconds before inserting data  (https://code.google.com/p/google-bigquery/issues/detail?id=191)
- Cleaned up code that does not adhere to PEP8
- Fixed issues with  `setUp` and `tearDown` in test_gbq.py

Ready for review. Ran unit tests in TestReadGBQIntegration & TestToGBQIntegration. All tests  passed.
@parthea1 did you mean to close this?

No, I didn't mean to close it. I think it closed automatically when I reverted my last commit. I thought it would be easier to revert my last commit, and submit a fresh one that takes into account all the feedback. I'm working on the new commit now. I think the PR will open again once I add a commit. 

Regarding the allowLargeResults feature (i.e. running a google big query without returning a dataframe) , do you think its better to add the following comment into #10474 and continue the discussion there?

> I have prepared 2 proposals in order to allow the user to choose to upload a Pandas Dataframe to a BigQuery table or run a SQL-Like query and have the results goto a BigQuery table. I will create a new PR once the decision is made.

My latest commit takes into account all the feedback in this PR, including: 
- Revert change to `read_gbq()`. (I will create a separate PR to support Google BigQuery allowLargeResult parameter)
- Update documentation in io.rst
- Add `delete_table()` function to the gbq module 
- Code refactoring

Ready for review. Ran unit tests in test_gbq. All tests passed.

Let me know if there is any other work needed for this PR. I have a few new pull requests that I want to create after this one.
1. Remove dependency on bq command line tool in `test_gbq.py`
2. Add ability to create and delete datasets using `create_dataset()` and `delete_dataset()`
3. Add support for BigQuery allowLargeResults #10474
cc @jacobschaer can you have a look?
I've updated the documentation with the required changes. Travis is green.

My latest commit takes into account all the feedback in this PR, including:
- Changes to the documentation for the gbq module in `io.rst`
- Additional error handling for http error as well as other errors that can occur while streaming data to BigQuery
- Create a sub section in `doc/source/whatsnew/v0.17.0.txt` for enhancements to the `gbq` module
- Ensure all links are formatted correctly
- Add a separate function in the `gbq module` for checking imports
- Add unit test `test_upload_data_dataset_not_found()`

Ready for review. Ran unit tests in test_gbq. All tests passed.

@parthea1 let's scale back a lot on the exception handling code. Its not tested and doesn't add value over simply re-raising. 

As I said above catching a http error in the middle of an insertion (and raising a nice miessage is fine).

Just use `ValueError` for everything (a couple of custom exceptions are ok, e.g. AuthorizationError) or whatever, but not too many. Its just confusing and not tested.

overall looks good though.

If you can make those changes we can put this in 0.17.0
@jorisvandenbossche can you have a look?

@parthea1 Looks like a nice enhancement! I put a bunch of comments, but it are just small things on the documentation formatting

I agree with @jreback that all the different custom exception classes are not needed. Just a clear error message is way more important
I've implemented all the changes. Waiting for Travis.
Travis is green.

Is it ok to use the latest version of google-api-python-client `1.4.2`, instead of `1.2`?

All unit tests in `test_gbq.py` pass in my local environment with `1.4.2`.

The only change I would recommend after updating to `1.4.2` is to change `apiclient` to `googleapiclient`. `apiclient` is an alias for `googleapiclient`

see https://github.com/google/google-api-python-client/blob/master/apiclient/__init__.py

Great! I'll keep an eye out for the pip files.

While I was resolving the import error, I ran into the issue mentioned in #10656 where `LooseVersion` does not treat `'1.2'` and `'1.2.0'` as equal. I think the solution is to use `StrictVersion`. I've added the commit that fixes the version check.

Here is a comparison of `LooseVersion` and `StrictVersion`

```
>>> from distutils.version import LooseVersion
>>> a = LooseVersion('1.2')
>>> b = LooseVersion('1.2.0')
>>> a == b
False
>>> from distutils.version import StrictVersion
>>> c = StrictVersion('1.2')
>>> d = StrictVersion('1.2.0')
>>> c == d
True
```

ok gr8!

having tests that work on Travis will be a big help 

even better would be a test project id (iirc that is hard to get) - thiugh I can prob set some up

Getting all the tests working with a test project id could be done using the following steps:
- [ ] Create a google account
- [ ] Register for BigQuery, and create a ProjectId
- [ ] Set the project id in `test_gbq.py`. Run the unit test and go through the authentication process.
- [ ] Copy the file that is generated : `pandas/io/tests/bigquery_credentials.dat` 
- [ ] Place the `bigquery_credentials.dat` into `pandas/io/tests/` at the start of each build.

I have seen an advertisement from BigQuery with a 2 month(or $300) free trial.
https://cloud.google.com/free-trial/

We've tried several times to work something out with Google for this and haven't gotten anywhere. Ideally they would provide an account just for integration testing for this project - perhaps liming access to Travis IP, etc. @azbones - have we heard anything back from them?

@parthea - that's basically what we did.
1) Created BigQuery account
2) Ran gbq once to generate the credentials file
3) Put the credentials file on a server with Jenkins
4) Jenkins runs on commit, moving the credentials file to the correct place and doing a string substitution with the project ID (in the test files).

The catch was that Jenkins needed to run at least often enough to keep the token valid, but that turned out to not be too big of an issue.

@jacobschaer
That's great! So everything is in place except a free account for integration testing which may take some time. Is it possible to use a BigQuery trial in the meantime? That should buy us 2 months. At the same time, we can understand what the cost would be for a paid account (you can see how long the $300 lasts in the trial), and it will also give us a change to tell Google what we're using it for in hopes that we can get an account for integration testing. It may help open the communications with Google.
